comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: If that Mundia genealogy (www.mundia.com/ca/Person/10113430/-216903987) is correct, Frederick Leslie’s parents were: Henry Allbeury (1849-1910) and Harriet Esther Attride (1861-1898) His siblings were: Theodore Henri Allbeury (1883-1922) Ernest A Allbeury (1885-?) Horace A Allbeury (1887- ?) Frank Le Boutillier Allbeury (1888-1917) Henrietta F Allbeury (1888- ?) Albert Cecil Le Boutillier Allbeury (1890-1964) And he married: Helen Macklin (1895- ?)

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: If so, at least two of his brothers served in the Army during the First World War. Temporary 2nd Lieut Theodore H. Allbeury relinquished his commission in the Black Watch (Royal Highlanders) on account of ill-health, 19 March 1916: www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/29513/supplements/3032 Frank Le Boutilier Allbeury (an RSM in the Border Regiment) died on the 23rd April 1917 and is commemorated on the Arras Memorial: www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/738428/ALLBEURY,%20FR... Before that, he was also awarded the MM and DCM: “8334 Sjt. Le B. Allbeury, Bord. R.” was awarded the Military Medal, 11 November 1916: www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/29819/supplements/10917 “8334 Sjt. F. le B. Allbeury, Bord. R.” awarded the Distinguished Conduct Medal, “For conspicuous gallantry in action. He proceeded along the enemy trench and effected the capture of 12 prisoners. He set a splendid example of courage and devotion to duty,” 12 March 1917: www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/29981/supplements/2480

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: I have not researched L F Allbeury's brother Albert Cecil Le Boutillier Allbeury (1890-1964) other than to find his birth recorded as Albert Cecil Allbeury in Camberwell 2nd qr 1890 and to also discover through tracing backwards through FreeBMD records that he is a forebear of Major Nicholas Le Boutillier ALLBEURY (489481), The Prince of Wales's Own Regiment of Yorkshire who received an MBE in the 1995 New Year Honours List en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1995_New_Year_Honours

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: I have enquired of Ret'd Major Nicholas Le Boutillier Allbeury for more information at boards.ancestry.com/surnames.leboutillier/1/mb.ashx He says he has accumulated a lot of information on the Le Boutillier name.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: These are the name details of the Allbeury siblings in another tree Theodore Harry Attride Allbeury Alfred Ernest Attride Allbeury Horace Arthur Attride Allbeury Netty F. Allbeury Albert Cecil Allbeury Leslie Frederick “Davide Cavendish” Allbeury This last has produced another name to research. www.david-attride.net/Attride_Genealogy/Attride_files/wc0... "California Death index also lists death for David Cavendish with same birth and death info, so apparently, David Cavendish is his actor name." www.david-attride.net/Attride_Genealogy/Attride_files/ps0... The actor attribution is unlikely as real name and dates of this actor are Den(n)is D'Auburn 29 October 1893, England, UK - 9 October 1960 - noted in many places. Is there a likeness? www.fulltv.tv/movies/movies-with-david-cavendish.html No person by the name Dennis D'Auburn or similar could I find in 1901 census or freebmd.co.uk

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: It is very curious; there is a grave of a "David Cavendish" (with the same dates) in Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills), Los Angeles, Los Angeles County, California, USA: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=20032 IMDB entry at: www.imdb.com/name/nm0147076/?ref_=ttfc_fc_cl_t19 With regard to possible service with the London Regiment, the 28th (County of London) Battalion was a volunteer territorial unit , popularly known as the Artists Rifles. Many people would have passed through the Artists Rifles on their way to other units (but I'm not sure if that normally included the RNVR).

comment.author: 43688219@N00
comment._content: 1891 Census The family are recorded at 51 Kimberley Road, Camberwell, Peckham, London. Head of the household is Henry , aged 42 and a self-employed Betting Agent from the City of London.. His wife is Harriet H, aged 30 and from Peckham. Their children at this time are:- Theodore H………….aged 8.…………..born Peckham Ernest A……………..aged 6.…………..born Peckham Horace A…………….aged 4.………….born Peckham Hetty F………………aged 3.…………..born Dulwich Albert C……………..aged 11 months….born Peckham Things do not appear to be rosy in the Allbeury household when we go forward to the 1901 Census Of Henry and Harriet there is no obvious sign. The same is true of Theodore.and Ernest. Harriet’s non-appearance would be consistent with her passing away in 1900, but Henry seems to have abandoned his children. There is a Horace Arthur, aged 17 and born Dulwich, who is recorded at the Royal Naval Training base, HMS Pembroke, at Chatham, Kent. His rank then was “Domestic 3rd Class” There is an “Etta, aged 13 and born Camberwell, who along with a Frank Allbeury, aged 9 and also born Camberwell, are recorded as two of ten servant at 199 Upland Road, Camberwell. However things possibly become clearer when you notice that the head of the household is a Jane White who gives her occupation as Foster Mother, Camberwell Board of Guardians. Finally there is an Albert Cecil, aged 11 and from Camberwell, who was recorded as a Scholar boarding at an institution in South Manchester. The 25 children on the same page of the census, all aged between 8-14, come from London - Bethnal Green, Stepney, Camberwell, Dulwich, Putney, Clerkenwell and Battersea. It may be a co-incidence but the Army lists for the Anglo-Boer War include a T H Allbeury, which may account for Theodore.He was serving in the Royal Army Medical Corps. Horace Arthur’s Naval records tells us he was born 13th April 1884, Dulwich, London. He enlisted in 1900. His service number was 358328. discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/SearchUI/Details?uri=D6... When we get to the 1911 Census, the family penchant for changing names and the ease with which that surname could so easily be mis-transcribed means the children are very hard to find. There is a 26 year old Ernest, born Peckham, who was recorded as an Unemployed General Labourer. His marital status was not recorded but he was living as a boarder with the Smith family at 26 Frankham Street, Deptford, London. There is a 19 year old Albert, born Peckham Rye, London and working as a Bakers Assistant, who was recorded as a boarder at 52 Churchill Street, Stockport, City of Manchester. The marriage of a Henrietta F Allbeury to an Ernest L Green was recorded in the Southwark District of London in the October to December 1912 quarter. There were Silver War Badges issued to soldier 3939 Leslie Frederick Allbeury, 28th London Regiment, (Badge Number 78640) and T H Allbeury, Royal Highlanders (Badge Number 149310). So was Leslie invalided out of the Army and then re-enlisted in the Navy? Would explain the odd nature of his military career. Thats a comparatively low number for a SWB and is earlier than Theodore's - who we have it from the London Gazette resigned his commission in March 1916 The marriage of a Theodore Allbeury to a Florence Bailey was recorded in the January to March 1917 quarter in the Chorlton District of Lancashire - may be a co-incidence but that was also the District where his brother Albert was recorded on the 1911 census. There is a record of a Frederick Allbeury, born circa 1893 who sailed from London in 1922 bound for New York on the UK Outbound Passenger lists. I’m beginning to wonder if we haven’t mixed up two families or is it really a case of triumphing over adversity and lowly beginnings !.

comment.author: 43688219@N00
comment._content: The Silver War Badge was issued in the United Kingdom to service personnel who had been honourably discharged due to wounds or sickness during World War I. The badge, sometimes known as the Discharge Badge, Wound Badge or Services Rendered Badge, was first issued in September 1916, along with an official certificate of entitlement. The sterling silver lapel badge was intended to be worn in civilian clothes. It had been the practice of some women to present white feathers to apparently able-bodied young men who were not wearing the King's uniform. The badge was to be worn on the right breast while in civilian dress, it was forbidden to wear on a military uniform. Approximately 1,150,000 badges were issued, which had to be claimed and then approved. The numbers on the back of the badge kept changing during the war. Between September 1916 and March 1918, they were issued with just a number and were better quality than most stampings. Around 335,000 of these were issued. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_War_Badge Here are some army service numbers and corresponding joining dates for the Artists' Rifles: 3167 joined on 14th January 1915 3270 joined on 1st February 1915 3443 joined on 5th March 1915 3622 joined on 9th April 1915 3908 joined on 27th May 1915 4126 joined on 25th June 1915 armyservicenumbers.blogspot.co.uk/2009/01/28th-county-of-... (Frank was serial number 3939).
